Mid-January 1438, Late Afternoon

The winter light falls long through the solar's windows, casting amber bars across the maps and documents spread across the great table. The Imperial Muster Plan lies completed beneath Diego de Daza's careful hand, its costs tallied, its logistics mapped—42,650 florins to forge twelve thousand volunteers into something resembling a unified force.

Around you, the architecture of empire has taken shape in words and parchment. Don Álvaro stands at the table's far end, his scarred hands resting on the wood, the weight of his new responsibilities—head of the central imperial administration—settling visibly onto his shoulders. Diego de Daza gathers his papers with the satisfied precision of a man whose numbers have balanced. Captain Fernán de Vargas waits quietly, his tactical mind already turning over the summer exercises to come. In the shadows near the door, Isaac de Baeza observes everything and says nothing, as is his way.

Queen María of Aragon, Alfonso's widow, remains seated by the window. She has given her counsel on Naples—Marino Brancaccio, the lesser baron who held Castel dell'Ovo, her recommendation—and written her endorsement. Her observation lingers in the air: "You have surpassed Alfonso in five years." She meant it as praise. You wonder if she also meant it as warning.

The planning is done. Five territories. Four governors. One administrative framework that, God willing, will outlast any single reign. Now come the letters—to Don García in Granada, to Guillem de Santcliment in Valencia, to Brancaccio in Naples, to Don Juan de Sotomayor regarding Constantinople, to Sir Thomas Beaumont about the academy officers.

Don Álvaro straightens. "Shall I have the secretaries prepare the dispatches, Your Majesty? Or is there further business before we adjourn?"

Don Álvaro bows. "It shall be done, Your Majesty. By morning, riders will carry your letters to Granada, Valencia, Naples, Constantinople, and Beaumont's academy." He begins gathering the documents, already sorting them for the secretaries.

You rise, and the others rise with you. The business of empire gives way, for a few hours, to the business of family.

The walk from the solar to the royal apartments takes you through corridors grown familiar over five years of kingship. Queen María walks beside you, her widow's black a stark contrast to the warm tapestries lining the walls. She has aged since Alfonso's death—not dramatically, but in small ways. Grey at her temples. A stillness that was not there before.

"You will write to Brancaccio tonight?" you ask.

"Before Vespers," she confirms. "He will believe an endorsement from me more than a command from you. We were in Naples together when Alfonso took the city. He remembers." She pauses at a branching corridor. "I will leave you here. Give my love to Lucia and the little ones."

She turns toward the guest apartments, and you continue alone.

The nursery wing is never quiet.

You hear them before you see them—Teresa's high laugh, Fernando's voice raised in some argument, the clatter of wooden toys. A wet nurse emerges from one doorway carrying Nicolás, barely a month old, swaddled and sleeping. She curtsies as you pass.

In the main nursery chamber, you find ordered chaos. Catalina sits on a cushioned bench with a book—really reading, not pretending, her dark eyes moving across the Latin text with a focus that would suit a scholar twice her age. Fernando stands before a wooden castle, debating fiercely with his tutor about whether defenders or attackers have the advantage. Teresa toddles between them, clutching a wooden horse and making whinnying sounds. Bianca sits alone by the fire, staring into the flames with an intensity that suggests she is either very happy or about to cry—with Bianca, it could be either.

Little Juana crawls toward you the moment you enter, her dark eyes fixing on your face with that strange, unblinking attention she has shown since birth.

Lucia rises from her chair by the window, where she had been supervising the whole swirl. At twenty-nine, four children have not diminished her beauty, though there is a weariness around her eyes that was not there when you married her. She crosses to you, takes your hand.

"The empire is built for another day?" she asks, grey-green eyes searching your face. "You have that look. The one where you've decided something enormous and haven't told me yet."

The Casa de las Palomas—the House of Doves—sits within its modest walls at Toledo's edge, far enough from the Alcázar to feel like home rather than court. Here, among the fruit trees and the small chapel and the sounds of children at play, the heirs of Castile grow up alongside Pedro, the tanner's son who matches Fernando in age and stubbornness, and little Lucía—not the Queen, but the weaver's daughter with her perpetual charcoal-stained fingers and her endless drawings.

Here, a king can simply be a father.

You settle into the worn chair by the hearth—your chair, the one with the armrest smoothed by years of use. Bianca comes to you immediately, as if she had been waiting, and you lift her onto your lap. She is trembling slightly, that intensity still in her face, but as your arms close around her she releases a shuddering breath and melts against your chest. At three, she is already heartbreakingly beautiful—Lucia's grey-green eyes in a face that somehow surpasses even her mother's legendary features. And so fragile. Always so fragile.

"Papá," she whispers, and burrows closer.

Catalina closes her book with the careful deliberation of a scholar—she will want to find her place again later—and crosses to stand at your right hand. Almost six now, dark-haired like her mother Isabel, brilliant and commanding and utterly empty of the faith that drives her father. She watches you with those knowing eyes.

Fernando abandons his siege debate and comes to your left, standing straight as a little soldier, his magnificent frame already hinting at the man he will become. Pedro, his companion, hangs back uncertainly until Fernando gestures him forward. Teresa follows her brother, wooden horse still clutched in her fist, and plops down at your feet with the uncomplicated happiness that is her gift.

María, your sister, appears in the doorway. Widowed, returned home, finding purpose in this strange household. She leans against the frame and listens.

Queen Lucia gathers Juana into her arms and settles into the chair across from you, the baby watching you with that unsettling, ancient attention. Somewhere in the next room, a wet nurse rocks Nicolás.

The fire crackles. The children wait.

Fernando breaks first, as he always does. "What's happening in summer, Father?"

This summer there is going to be a muster. Soldiers gathering in the kingdom. We will be there as well. And the children who are old enough to come along will come with me as well. There's no petulance in it—just a statement of fact, delivered with the quiet certainty of someone who has never doubted herself. "Fernando is the one who complains when his boots get wet."

Catalina's lips curve slightly—not quite a smile, but close. "Lucía can come. If she wants to. But as a companion, not a nursemaid." Catalina settles into the saddle with careful precision, gathering the reins exactly as she was taught years ago in Madrid. She remembers the theory perfectly—heels down, back straight, hands quiet. But memory and muscle are different things. The mare shifts beneath her, and Catalina's corrections come a half-beat too slow, her commands a touch too tentative. She rides a circuit of the paddock without incident, but there is no flow to it, no conversation between horse and rider.

She knows it, too. You can see it in the tightening of her jaw as she dismounts—that particular frustration of a brilliant mind confronting something that cannot be mastered through study alone.

"I need practice," she says flatly. Not an excuse. An assessment.

Pedro whoops with delight and puts the animal through its paces with an instinct that owes nothing to training and everything to raw, God-given gift.

She looks up at you, and for just a moment, beneath the brilliance and the composure, there is a five-year-old girl asking her father if she is enough.
